tweets.text: “At Yale, administrative positions have soared over 150% in the last two decades. But the number of professors increased by just 10%. In a new low/high, Stanford recently enrolled 16,937 undergraduate and graduate students, but lists 15,750 administrative staff — near one-to-one”

It turns out that Teamsters have a Biden-put that fully insulates them from tightening monetary policy. 

Must be nice.

Where is the equity here?

Agree, *most* “crypto” is garbage.

However, both BTC and ETH are in fact: 1) useful for payments (portable/divisible/verifiable); 2) hedges to expansionary monetary policy; 3) provably scare; 4) taxable like any other currency/asset/property; 5) open source innovation platforms. https://t.co/S6EEA8hTow

Exactly this. An important message because it’s not how mainstream press or even FinTwit writ large is spinning things. 

Failure of centralized, opaque, human led organizations (which SHOULD be better regulated) not failure of decentralized, open source crypto networks/assets! https://t.co/BZ94IEVWEE

If true, the apparent preference (and exploitation thereof) for redemptions from FTX by Bahamian citizens is such a farce. 

No non-Bahamian citizen will ever again interface with a Bahamian domiciled financial institution. 

Or perhaps I’m missing something.
